# fibonacci-sequence-golden-ratio

just found out that the ratio of 2 consecutive Fibonacci numbers tend to the golden ratio as the numbers increases.
wrote a little program to demo it.

Ivan Shim 2021 July 20th

output:

index, fibonacci, ratio
1, 1, 1
2, 1, 2
3, 2, 1.5
4, 3, 1.6666666666667
5, 5, 1.6
6, 8, 1.625
7, 13, 1.6153846153846
8, 21, 1.6190476190476
9, 34, 1.6176470588235
10, 55, 1.6181818181818
11, 89, 1.6179775280899
12, 144, 1.6180555555556
13, 233, 1.618025751073
14, 377, 1.6180371352785
15, 610, 1.6180327868852
16, 987, 1.6180344478217
17, 1597, 1.6180338134001
18, 2584, 1.6180340557276
19, 4181, 1.6180339631667
20, 6765, 1.6180339985218
21, 10946, 1.6180339850174
22, 17711, 1.6180339901756
23, 28657, 1.6180339882053
24, 46368, 1.6180339889579
25, 75025, 1.6180339886704
26, 121393, 1.6180339887802
27, 196418, 1.6180339887383
28, 317811, 1.6180339887543
29, 514229, 1.6180339887482
30, 832040, 1.6180339887505
31, 1346269, 1.6180339887496
32, 2178309, 1.61803398875
33, 3524578, 1.6180339887499
34, 5702887, 1.6180339887499
35, 9227465, 1.6180339887499
36, 14930352, 1.6180339887499
37, 24157817, 1.6180339887499
38, 39088169, 1.6180339887499
39, 63245986, 1.6180339887499
40, 102334155, 1.6180339887499

golden ratio: 1.6180339887499
the ratio of 2 consecutive Fibonacci numbers tends to the golden ratio as n increases
